stem: The labor and delivery nurse is managing four clients in active labor. Based on the documentation in the Intrapartum Assessment & Intervention Log, match each FHR pattern to the priority nursing action.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: G1P0; 8cm dilated. FHR shows early decelerations mirroring contractions. 
Patient B: G3P2; 6cm dilated. FHR shows recurrent late decelerations (present on >50% of contractions in 20 min). 
Patient C: G1P0; 4cm dilated. FHR shows intermittent variable decelerations with normal baseline. 
Patient D: G2P1; 5cm dilated. FHR shows a persistent baseline of 180 bpm for the last 30 minutes.

tabs.title: Intrapartum Assessment & Intervention Log
tabs.content:
PatientPatternBaseline VariabilityStatus
AEarly DecelsModerateCategory I
BRecurrent LatesMinimalCategory II / III
CIntermittent VariablesModerateCategory II
DBaseline TachycardiaModerateCategory II

columns.text: Action: Oxygen 10L via mask + Side-lying position
Action: Reposition client + Observe for improvement

rationale.correct: Early decelerations (r1) are normal head compressions and only require observation (c1). Late decelerations (r2) require immediate intrauterine resuscitation (O2, fluids, side-lying) (c2). Variables (r3) require a position change to relieve cord pressure (c3). Tachycardia (r4) usually indicates maternal fever or dehydration (c4).
clinicalPearls: Lates = BAD. Oxygen is ALWAYS 10L via non-rebreather mask.
Earlys = GOOD. It means the baby's head is moving down.
If you see a Pattern II or III, the first action is usually 'Turn the patient' (Reposition).

questionTrap.trap: Stopping Pitocin for an Early Deceleration.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Never stop the labor (Pitocin) for a normal finding. Early decels are fine.
